awd_titl_txt: Attosecond Processes and Strong Field Physics
awd_abstract_narration:
We  study the interaction of attosecond pulses, which last for less than one femtosecond, with matter. In particular, we study the interaction of short (ultraviolet) wavelength (ultraviolet) attosecond pulses with matter subjected to a delayed  laser pulse with a much longer (near infrared) wavelength. These near-infrared-extreme untraviolet (nir-xuv) pulse pairs are automatically available when attosecond radiation is made by the strong ﬁeld process of high harmonic generation. These two-color pulse pairs have a wide variety of uses, from attosecond metrology to the control of strong ﬁeld processes such as multiphoton ionization. The short duration of the pulses and the strength of the applied ﬁelds dictate that accurate calculations require a nonperturbative solution of the laser-matter interaction, which we achieve by direct integration of the time-dependent Schrodinger equation. The work is directly relevant to ongoing collaborations between the principle investigator and experimental groups at the forefront of strong ﬁeld physics and attosecond science.

Attosecond light allows us to study and manipulate atomic, molecular and biological processes at sub-femtosecond time scales, yielding new ways to understand and control matter via its interaction with light. The basic research on attosecond physics supported by this project will broaden the U.S. knowledge base on attosecond science.  The research will result in the training of graduate students and postdoctoral research associates in the interdisciplinary ﬁeld of atomic, molecular and optical science. They will gain a broad education in both atomic physics and high intensity laser science, and a thorough understanding of both the theoretical and experimental issues involved. They will also receive training in advanced numerical simulations, with applications to a wide variety of problems in government and industry. The research topics supported by the grant will be incorporated into the PI's teaching of time-dependent quantum dynamics at both the undergraduate and graduate levels.

por.por_cntn:
This proposal has focused on the study attosecond physics, strong field physics, and the connections between these two areas. Indeed, making the connection between attosecond science and strong field physics formed the basis for the intellectual merit of this project. In service of this goal we studied the interaction of attosecond, extreme ultraviolet (XUV) pulses with matter subjected to a delayed near-to-mid-infrared (NIR) laser pulse. These nir-xuv pulse pairs are automatically available when attosecond radiation is made by the strong field process of high harmonic generation. They have a wide variety of uses, from attosecond metrology to the control of strong field processes such as multiphoton ionization. The short duration of the pulses and the strength of the applied fields dictate that accurate calculations require a non-perturbative solution of the laser-matter interaction, which we achieved by direct integration of the time-dependent Schrödinger equation (TDSE). The work was directly relevant to ongoing collaborations between the principle investigator and experimental groups at the forefront of strong field physics and attosecond science.

Attosecond light sources offer a way to study and manipulate atomic, molecular and biological processes at sub-femtosecond time scales, yielding new ways to understand and control matter via its interaction with light. Among the broader impacts of our work, the expansion of basic knowledge and research in the U.S. on attosecond science stands out. This field, which is in the vanguard of atomic physics and physical chemistry, is dominated by European laboratories at the present time. The research has also resulted in the training of graduate students and postdoctoral research associates in the interdisciplinary field of atomic, molecular and optical science. They have gained a broad education in both atomic physics and high intensity laser science, and a thorough understanding of both the theoretical and experimental issues involved. They have also receive training in advanced numerical simulations  (with applications to a wide variety of problems in government and industry).

The main outcomes of our research fell into three broad categories:

(i) The development of new numerical methods for solving the TDSE including correlation in two electron models;

(ii) Calculation and analysis of angular-resolved momentum distributions from strong mid-infrared laser fields;

(iii) Attosecond control of strong field processes, including electron wave packet interferometry and attosecond control of non-sequential double ionization.

The usefulness of electron wave packets created either near and below an ionization threshold by an attosecond pulse was a theme common to all of these projects. As a particular example we can cite our study of quantum beats in the photoelectron signal produced when a bound electron wave packet created by an isolated attosecond pulse is ionized by a delayed, few-cycle infrared pulse. This topic was explored as part of a collaboration with an experimental attosecond science group in Milan. The idea was to create attosecond electron wave packets below the ionization threshold in helium and subsequently ionize them with a few cycle NIR pulse. Our calculations for helium atoms showed that the broad bandwidth of the few-cycle pulse can be used to create spectrally overlapping photoelectron peaks that result from one-, two-, or three-photon ionization processes. We showed that the beat signals can, in principle, be interferometrically resolved with high resolution, giving access to the relative phase between different multiphoton ionization pathways. For few-cycle NIR fields the relative spectral phases can be extracted over a large energy region, and dynamical information becomes available. We found that multiphoton ionization is temporally shifted with respect to one-photon ionization by several hundred attoseconds. Our results also revealed the impact that depletion and resonant pathways have on the phase of the quantum beats. We expect that experiments in the coming year will make extensive use of these results.
